nacimiento.title: The Birth of the Empire
nacimiento.intro_p1: The Empire of Aevora was born from the ashes of the British monarchy following a coup d'état orchestrated in 1868. Under the cold, visionary leadership of Norland Reaventhorn, an alliance of powerful industrial and noble houses rose against the old regime, driven by the discovery of a revolutionary resource: Aevar. This mineral, capable of generating steam of extraordinary power, became the bedrock of a new order founded upon technology, efficiency, and iron-fisted control.
nacimiento.intro_p2: Since then, Aevora has stood as a strictly hierarchical and regulated society, where steam machinery and steel define progress. It is an empire that prioritises obedience over liberty, production over the individual, and expansion over diplomacy—governed by an implacable philosophy that views technology as the future of humanity, regardless of the cost.

sociedad.title: Society
sociedad.intro_p1: Following the consolidation of the Empire, the social structure was redefined to function as a strictly hierarchical system, where every individual occupied a fixed place destined to preserve stability and state control. Cohesion no longer depended on consensus, but on obedience.
sociedad.intro_p2: From this principle arises a rigid order in which birth and function become inseparable. Every stratum, from the Founding Houses to the labourers, is integrated as part of a social machinery designed to sustain the imperial project without deviations.

poder.title: Power
poder.intro_p1: In the Empire of Aevora, power is the iron backbone upon which the imperial order rests, a system as perfectly oiled as it is lethal. For Norland Reaventhorn, military force was not an instrument of conquest, but the purest expression of logic. A hierarchical organism, disciplined and devoid of sentimentality, where every cog fulfils its function within the great machine of the Empire.
poder.intro_p2: Thus was born, and is perpetuated, the Steam Legion, the Aevorian army. It is not a militia, nor a Praetorian Guard; it is the extended arm of the imperial will, a pyramidal structure as rigid as the steel of its Guardians and as cold as the steam that fuels its engines.

tecnologia.title: War Technology
tecnologia.intro_p1: In the Empire of Aevora, technology is not a tool; every spark of steam, every cog of a Guardian, every pressure rifle, is a verse in the dogma of imperial progress. Here, innovation does not seek to improve life, but to perfect the art of submission and conquest. It is a cold discipline, directed by the Imperial Council and fuelled by the obsession of Norland Reaventhorn: to create a war machine so perfect that its mere existence deters any challenge.
tecnologia.intro_p2: The Aevar is the soul of this technological crusade, and its opalescent glimmers illuminate the path towards a future where man and machine merge to serve a single purpose: the eternal power of the Empire.

contexto.title: Historical Context
contexto.content_1: The First Industrial Revolution profoundly transformed the global economic and political system. However, towards the mid-19th century, the European powers that had driven this process began to show signs of strain. Each nation faced particular conditions that limited its ability to maintain global leadership.
contexto.content_2: The United Kingdom, a pioneer in industrialisation, was going through a process of slow but perceptible decline. The loss of the American colonies had generated a lasting impact that technological advances could not entirely conceal. Although the factories continued to operate intensely, the maintenance of the vast empire entailed increasingly high costs. Added to this was an unequal distribution of wealth, making it evident that British prosperity was beginning to weaken. The industrial apparatus, formerly a symbol of dynamism, was starting to show signs of structural fatigue.
contexto.content_3: France was experiencing a different situation, marked by political instability. Over the course of a few decades, the country transitioned between regimes that succeeded one another without consolidation: the legacy of Napoleon, the return of the monarchy, the establishment of the republic, and the arrival of the Second Empire under Napoleon III. Although the French economy was solid and its army possessed great operational capacity, the country lacked internal cohesion. The succession of crises and institutional changes weakened its capacity to exercise sustained hegemony in Europe.
contexto.content_4: In the centre of the continent, the Germanic region remained fragmented into multiple states. Nevertheless, Prussia was emerging as the most dynamic power, with an expanding industry and an accelerated modernisation of its infrastructure, especially in metallurgy and railways. Its military and institutional discipline laid the foundations for the future German unification in 1871. At the same time, the Austrian Empire faced problems derived from its complex ethnic composition. Although it retained notable diplomatic weight, its economic and social structure remained stagnant, hindering its adaptation to industrial modernity.
contexto.content_5: The Russian Empire presented a notable contrast. Its enormous territorial extent and numerous army granted it an indisputable presence, but it continued to function under a system close to feudalism. Its economy, predominantly agricultural, reflected considerable backwardness in comparison with the Western powers. The abolition of serfdom in 1861 evidenced both the magnitude of the delay and the urgent need for reforms that would still take time to materialise.
contexto.content_6: Italy and the Iberian Peninsula completed the picture. Italy remained divided into multiple kingdoms without political cohesion capable of driving a common project. Spain and Portugal, in this alternate timeline, still retained a significant part of their domains in Latin America, which provided them with a certain international weight. However, their low level of industrialisation and dependence on agrarian economies prevented them from competing on equal terms with the more advanced powers. Despite the size of their armies, their military technology showed a considerable lag.
contexto.content_7: As the century advanced, the contradictory effects of industrialisation became more visible. While it generated wealth and growth, it also created deep inequalities, accelerated the consumption of natural resources, and unleashed increasingly intense social tensions.
contexto.content_8: In the United Kingdom, these tensions manifested with special clarity. The landed nobility maintained political control, whilst the industrial and financial bourgeoisie, who had driven the country's economic development, demanded greater participation in State decisions. Although their investments sustained the empire's economy, political recognition remained concentrated in a monarchy that many perceived as disconnected from the new productive reality.
contexto.content_9: The economic crises that affected the country in the middle of the century deepened this discontent. Business groups began to consider that the monarchy, represented by a Queen Victoria identified with a traditional and static order, constituted an obstacle to progress. In the economic centres of London, the idea of a radical transformation in the structure of British power then began to take shape.

aevar.title: Discovery of the Aevar
aevar.content_1: The discovery of the Aevar occurred in an African colony neglected by the metropolis, exploited almost exclusively for its mineral resources. In a mine belonging to House Finch, an unknown mineral appeared with an opalescent sheen which, upon being refined, emitted a vapour of extraordinary power and purity. Subsequently named Aevar, this material surpassed coal and oil in efficiency and thermal stability, opening the possibility of a profound transformation in steam-based technology.
aevar.content_2: At first, the mineral was considered merely a curiosity with limited industrial applications. However, the most ambitious families of British high society, amongst them engineers, bankers, and innovators in the field of armaments, quickly identified the strategic potential of the Aevar. In a country experiencing a progressive decline, the appearance of that substance was interpreted as an opportunity to recover lost influence and aspire to a new cycle of national expansion. For these elites, the Aevar became a symbol of renewal and a possible foundation for a new political and economic order.
aevar.content_3: Despite its energetic promise, the Aevar presented critical limitations. Its extraction was only viable under very specific conditions, as the deposits were located at depths exceeding five hundred metres and required a rare geological composition. This restricted its availability to a few mines situated in African colonies. Furthermore, the mineral proved unstable in its raw state. Direct exposure produced accelerated cellular deterioration, known as the Marking, whose main symptoms included intense fever, reddish pigmentation of the skin, and death in prolonged cases. These characteristics meant that both extraction and handling required strict procedures and highly specialised personnel.
aevar.content_4: The first attempts to control the Aevar were marked by serious accidents. In a hidden laboratory of House Finch, a stabilisation experiment using overpressure provoked an explosion that caused the death of three researchers and left a considerable crater. This incident, known as the Cairnmore Disaster, prompted a young Norland Reaventhorn, right-hand man of Sir Alexander Finch, to completely revise the methods utilised. From that moment, trials were conducted in reinforced chambers and with test animals. It was discovered that continuous exposure to the refined vapour of the Aevar granted the subjects strength and stamina superior to humans, although it also generated a severe physiological dependence. The interruption of the supply caused rapid and painful physical deterioration.

norlandOyA.title: Norland Reaventhorn: Ascent
norlandOyA.content_1: Norland's trajectory was marked by a modest origin within the minor nobility. His childhood was conditioned by the weak and compliant character of his father, who subordinated himself to more powerful houses in exchange for marginal influence. A humiliating episode during a banquet at the Harrington mansion profoundly marked the young Norland and consolidated in him the purpose of surpassing those families who looked down upon the Reaventhorns.
norlandOyA.content_2: Norland's ambition was cemented during his time as an assistant to Sir Alexander Finch in the African colonies. There, supervising the mining exploitation with an iron fist and repressing revolts, he internalised that power was a conquest, not a legacy, operating in an environment where life lacked value. It was during this period that the Aevar was initially discovered, although at that moment it was only catalogued as a curious geological phenomenon. After Finch's passing in an accident during an inspection, Norland returned to England, having inherited his mentor's fortune and mining concessions, with sufficient resources to initiate his social climb.
norlandOyA.content_3: Shortly after his return, the death of his father, the Reaventhorn patriarch, in an event shrouded in rumour, elevated Norland to the head of the family. At thirty years of age, with a solid academic background and vast experience in the steel and engineering sector, the new Norland Reaventhorn demonstrated a sharp strategic intelligence and great social skill. He immediately understood that the Aevar was much more than a source of energy; it was a key instrument to mould the future of England.
norlandOyA.content_4: In an early phase, Norland acted on the margins of the Crown's attention, which did not yet understand the relevance of the Aevar. He held discreet meetings with representatives of the principal noble and industrial houses and presented the mineral as the key to recovering British supremacy. His carefully articulated discourse spread amongst the most influential salons of London, where the tensions between aristocracy and bourgeoisie were being debated. Over time, the idea that the monarchy was impeding progress began to gain ground.
norlandOyA.content_5: In this context, Norland developed a structured plan that consisted of forming a clandestine alliance of powerful families willing to overthrow the monarchy and rebuild the Empire under the principles of modern industry and the harnessing of the Aevar. This group consolidated itself as The Society of the Twelve. The principal houses that integrated this initial circle were the following:
norlandOyA.content_6: Armstrong: Specialists in military engineering and the manufacture of heavy weaponry, capable of contributing decisive military capability.
norlandOyA.content_7: Cunard: Leaders in maritime transport, whose fleet ensured supremacy on the trade routes.
norlandOyA.content_8: Vickers: A reference in metallurgy and industrial precision, fundamental for the mechanical infrastructure of the new order.
norlandOyA.content_9: Rothschild: One of the most influential banking dynasties in Europe, essential for large-scale financing.
norlandOyA.content_10: Barings: Another key financial actor, with experience in colonial markets and international trade networks.
norlandOyA.content_11: Brunel: A family of prominent engineers, responsible for great works and indispensable technical advances.
norlandOyA.content_12: Lovelace: Closely linked to the security of the royal family; their participation proved especially risky but valuable for obtaining internal intelligence.
norlandOyA.content_13: Alderfost: Specialists in steam cooling systems, necessary to regulate the energetic flow of the Aevar.
norlandOyA.content_14: Pelwright: Chemists focussed on the study and perfection of the mineral's refinement.
norlandOyA.content_15: Fenmarsh: Exporters of heavy machinery, responsible for covering up the first shipments of Aevar under legitimate commercial activities.
norlandOyA.content_16: Ashmere: Editors and media proprietors, charged with moulding public opinion and weakening the image of the monarchy.
norlandOyA.content_17: Under the coordination of Norland Reaventhorn, these families established a cohesive structure dedicated to re-defining the future of the Empire. The meetings were held at the Reaventhorn residence in Yorkshire, a place isolated and protected by strict commitments of confidentiality and by a carefully administered network of loyalties.

oportunidad.title: The Perfect Storm
oportunidad.content_1: The financial crisis of 1868 represented the turning point that allowed for the collapse of the British political system and facilitated the execution of the coup planned by Norland Reaventhorn and the Society of the Twelve. Although at first glance it appeared to be an industrial recession of national scope, its impact revealed previously existing structural flaws in both the economy and the governance of the United Kingdom. These flaws, accumulated over decades, generated an environment exceptionally propitious for the substitution of the monarchical order with a political model centred on industrial efficiency and technocracy.
oportunidad.content_2: Social and economic discontent was amplified simultaneously on several fronts. The rural nobility experienced constant losses due to the fall in agricultural prices and demanded governmental support that never arrived. On the other hand, the industrial bourgeoisie found itself increasingly stifled by taxes, debts, and the lack of state investment in critical infrastructure. This sector, essential for national stability, began to perceive that the monarchy was incapable of adapting to the demands of the new industrial cycle.
oportunidad.content_3: The figure of Norland Reaventhorn emerged in this context as a tangible alternative to institutional stagnation. His ability to present solutions based on technical rationalisation, productive modernisation, and state reorganisation generated growing sympathy amongst the economic elites. The newspapers controlled by House Ashmere reinforced this perception by disseminating an image of Norland as a necessary reformer.
oportunidad.content_4: While Parliament debated measures that failed to materialise, public confidence in the monarchy diminished rapidly. The streets of London filled with discontented workers, factories reduced their activity, and the sensation that the country lacked effective political direction became generalised. Together, these elements formed the perfect storm, a scenario in which the State became vulnerable, the population was exhausted, and the elites sought leadership capable of restoring order and offering stability.
oportunidad.content_5: This climate of institutional collapse was not, however, a spontaneous phenomenon solely exploited by the conspiracy, but also an environment that Norland had foreseen and analysed for years. For him and the Society of the Twelve, the crisis was not the trigger for the coup, but the necessary condition to execute it without significant resistance.

preparativos.title: Covert Preparations
preparativos.content_1: As the crisis advanced and the government lost cohesion, the Society of the Twelve intensified a set of discreet operations that, in appearance, bore no relation to one another. Their true purpose, however, was to prepare the ground for a controlled collapse of the State. Nothing that occurred during those months was spontaneous: every incident, every delay, every blackout, and every technical failure formed part of a carefully designed invisible architecture.
preparativos.content_2: Factories dependent on royal contracts began to experience apparently random breakdowns. Boilers that had functioned for years burst without prior warning; entire assembly lines halted due to pressure failures that no one could explain.
preparativos.content_3: Meanwhile, the trains supplying the industrial cities began to fail at critical moments. Entire convoys vanished onto secondary routes, diverted from their original destinations without leaving official records. In other cases, rails were found twisted or misaligned at dawn after nights during which no one seemed to have worked.
preparativos.content_4: Urban disorder increased when London suffered a series of simultaneous explosions in its main steam conduits. The population believed it to be the inevitable collapse of an obsolete and saturated system. Only the Society knew that those bursts had been provoked through minuscule adjustments in pressure levels, carried out weeks earlier.
preparativos.content_5: In parallel, within the ministries and the Crown's inner circle, information ceased to flow reliably. Messages that should have arrived in hours took days; military orders disappeared before reaching their destinations; even naval communications began to present inexplicable gaps. House Lovelace supervised this infiltration from the shadows, constructing a network of informants that converted every government decision into a predictable move. The monarchy was acting blindly without knowing it.
preparativos.content_6: In the banks of London, the atmosphere became uncertain. Carefully distributed rumours provoked massive withdrawals of funds, and several financial entities began to show signs of insolvency. The Crown attempted to contain the situation but discovered that its reserves were insufficient to stem the panic.
preparativos.content_7: Norland Reaventhorn followed the progress of these actions with a serenity that disconcerted even his allies. He did not need to give direct orders; each House knew exactly which piece it had to move and when to do so. He limited himself to adjusting the pace, ensuring that all failures appeared natural, inevitable, and alien to any human intervention. When the system began to crumble, Norland no longer needed to convince anyone that the country required a new direction. The collapse, carefully orchestrated, spoke for itself.

diaP.title: The Night of the Regicide
diaP.content_1: When the unrest reached its peak and London burned beneath plumes of smoke visible from miles away, Norland Reaventhorn considered that the necessary conditions for the final outcome had been met. No institution was functioning normally, garrisons were receiving contradictory orders, and the population was divided between fear and indignation. The monarchy, isolated and ill-informed, acted without comprehending that the country had ceased to answer to its authority hours earlier.
diaP.content_2: In this context, the dinner hosted by Norland at his residence in Yorkshire was not a diplomatic gathering, but the culminating phase of a strategy that had been years in the making. Representatives of the principal noble and industrial houses, government officials, and Members of Parliament arrived at the mansion, many of them convinced that they were attending a meeting aimed at seeking a peaceful solution to the crisis. The reality was very different: that hall was to become the stage where the definitive break with the Crown would materialise.
diaP.content_3: Whilst the guests attempted to maintain their composure, the windows revealed reddish reflections on the horizon, caused by the fires consuming various districts of the capital. Tension mounted when rumours began to circulate regarding attacks on government buildings and riots outside Parliament. In that charged atmosphere, Norland calmly laid out his vision of the future: a State reorganised according to principles of industrial efficiency, free from monarchical inertia, and capable of steering the country towards a modernity that the Crown could not comprehend.
diaP.content_4: The surprise came when the doors of the hall opened and Alistair Lovelace entered, escorting Queen Victoria and her children. None of those present expected to see the Royal Family in that place, and even less so in the custody of the man who, until then, had served as their head of security. The emotional impact was immediate: the old order was literally there, stripped of power and placed before those who were about to decide the fate of the realm.
diaP.content_5: Norland then took one of the Aevar-powered weapons, an experimental model whose violet glow contrasted with the white of the walls. As he levelled the weapon at the Queen, his words were spoken with the calm of one delivering a conclusion, not a threat. The synchronisation with the final chime of Big Ben, carefully calculated thanks to the prior interruptions in the telegraph network, transformed the shot into a symbolic act.
diaP.content_6: The silence that followed was not merely one of shock, but also of comprehension. Many of those present understood that there was no longer a way back. The monarchy had been eliminated, and any attempt to oppose it at that moment signified certain death. Those who decided not to align themselves with the new order were removed immediately, whilst those who swore loyalty sealed their fate as founders of the regime that was emerging.
diaP.content_7: By dawn, the official narrative had already begun to take shape. The bodies would be buried in unmarked graves, the public would receive carefully manipulated explanations, and the symbols of the old regime would be removed without resistance. The execution of Queen Victoria was not presented as an act of usurpation, but as a necessary response to an order that had shown itself incapable of ensuring the country's survival. Thus, the night of the regicide became not only the end of a monarchy, but the founding act of the Empire of Aevora.

consecuencias.title: Immediate Consequences
consecuencias.content_1: The hours following the regicide marked a point of no return for the country. The death of Queen Victoria had not only dismantled the symbolic figure of power but had also left the United Kingdom without clear political guidance amidst the chaos. In that vacuum, the Society of the Twelve acted with a calculated speed that demonstrated the coup had not been a spontaneous act, but the culmination of a process of gradual state substitution.
consecuencias.content_2: Whilst the remnants of government buildings still burned in London and the population attempted to comprehend the events of the previous night, agents of House Lovelace began to execute pre-prepared lists. Key officials, generals of questionable loyalty, and nobles with the capacity to mobilise resistance were detained or eliminated in operations carried out with discretion and precision.
consecuencias.content_3: Prisons filled rapidly with individuals identified as potential dissidents. Many of them had not even acted against Norland; it sufficed that they possessed enough influence to become a future problem. In parallel, the first labour camps began to rise in remote areas, destined to contain those the new regime considered impossible to reintegrate.
consecuencias.content_4: However, resistance did not disappear immediately. In the industrial cities of the north, groups of workers reacted with desperation to the situation, attacking makeshift military installations with tools and machinery. In Scotland, some clans took advantage of the void to assert their independence, convinced that no central power could impose itself at that moment. But these reactions lacked coordination and were quelled with relative ease: the speed of the response demonstrated that the military infrastructure had come under Norland's direct control even before the Crown fell.
consecuencias.content_5: Within the Reaventhorn family itself, the most significant challenge arose. Eldric, Norland's younger brother, emerged as an unexpected figure of moral opposition. Although he lacked the political or military power to dispute control, his ability to articulate a discourse of resistance turned him into a dangerous symbol. His messages circulated clandestinely through universities, factories, and intellectual circles, reminding the population that an alternative to the new regime existed.
consecuencias.content_6: In a matter of days, the country left behind any attempt to restore the old order. Parliament was dissolved and replaced by the Imperial Council of Twelve Chairs, where each Founding House received a position in accordance with its contribution to the coup. The administrative map was redrawn, abandoning the traditional counties to make way for industrial districts controlled directly by the Houses.
consecuencias.content_7: These measures were not presented as a revolution, but as a rational reorganisation destined to guarantee the country's continuity. The population, exhausted after weeks of chaos and misinformation, largely accepted the transition, convinced that the new regime offered stability against the risk of total collapse.

amanecer.title: The Dawn of a New Era

era.title: The Dawn of a New Era
era.content_1: The early morning of 22 October 1868 found England immersed in a strange, almost unnatural silence. The smoke still rising from the charred remains of several London buildings mingled with a thick fog that obscured the rooftops. It was a grey, heavy dawn, as if the city itself were holding its breath, waiting to be redefined.
era.content_2: At that early hour, the first official communiqués began to circulate. The newspapers under the control of House Ashmere were already printed even before the majority of citizens had left their homes. Their headlines left no room for uncertainty: the events of the previous night were described as "the necessary purge for a new rebirth". The population, exhausted by weeks of chaos, barely had the strength to question it; they accepted the explanation as a refuge from the bewilderment.
era.content_3: The rumours regarding the Queen's death, which had swept through the streets during the night, vanished following the public appearance of a declaration issued by the newly formed Provisional Restoration Assembly. The document, signed by the Twelve Founding Houses, announced solemnly, and definitively, the birth of a new political order: the Empire of Aevora.
era.content_4: Norland Reaventhorn, now designated as First Regent of the Imperial Council, emerged as the undeniable face of the new era. His figure, imperturbable, projected itself over the country as a promise of stability and direction at a moment when both seemed to have been lost. The title he had been granted would not take long to transform into a more imposing one, driven not by tradition, but by the direct will of those moulding the new system: Emperor of Aevora.
era.content_5: The transition of power was immediate. The old Parliament was dissolved, and with it disappeared the structures of the monarchical regime. In its place, the Imperial Council of Twelve Chairs was established, a body where each Founding House occupied a seat proportional to its influence and participation in the coup. From that moment, the country's administration adopted a technical, cold, and calculated character, moving away from any reminiscence of the past.
era.content_6: Barely a few days had elapsed when the most visible transformations began. Engineers from Houses Armstrong and Brunel deployed to the great manufacturing centres to set in motion the so-called Total Reconversion. The old civil production chains were dismantled and replaced by lines dedicated to manufacturing parts for Guardians, steam weaponry, and heavy machinery. At the same time, telegraphic systems came under the absolute supervision of the Lovelaces, who established the Imperial Eye Network, a surveillance structure that intertwined the entire country via cables, codes, and loyal operators.
era.content_7: The sensation amongst the population was ambivalent: fear, relief, resignation. But above all, a palpable certainty that the time for debate had ended. The Empire did not ask for opinion; it demanded obedience.

semilla.title: The Seed of Rebellion
semilla.content_1: Although the Empire of Aevora was proclaimed with a rapidity that disoriented the population, the transition was not as absolute as the official communiqués claimed. Beneath the surface of the new order, something began to stir: slow, silent, almost imperceptible at first. However, that movement would be sufficient to threaten the stability that Norland was attempting to construct. The name of the catalyst was one that the Empire would have preferred to erase from the very first day: Eldric Reaventhorn.
semilla.content_2: Younger brother of the Emperor, relegated until then to a discreet role within the aristocracy, Eldric emerged as an unexpected figure of opposition. He possessed neither armies nor military alliances, but he held something more dangerous for a regime in gestation: a moral conviction capable of resonating amongst those who still remembered that alternatives to absolute control existed.
semilla.content_3: His messages began to circulate whilst the smoke of the coup still rose over London. They were not incendiary proclamations nor calls to violence; they were reflections, warnings, questions. Brief texts, copied by hand, that appeared in universities, factory workshops, and intellectual circles. Each one carried with it the same disquieting idea: that the new order had not been built to serve the people, but to subjugate them.
semilla.content_4: The agents of the Founding Houses did not take long to identify the threat. Those clandestine sheets, written with common ink on ordinary paper, had an effect that no weapon could replicate: they restored to the citizens the sensation that something had remained unsaid, that the official version concealed more than it revealed.
semilla.content_5: The workers who had accepted the Empire as the sole guarantee of stability began to murmur between shifts. The students, who had applauded the promise of a modernised country, wondered what price that uncontrolled efficiency would exact. Even some minor members of the nobility, sidelined from central decisions, found in Eldric's words an echo of their own silenced doubts.
semilla.content_6: The resistance possessed neither form nor direction yet. There were no leaders, nor organised cells, nor visible plans. It was merely a collection of scattered thoughts, an unease that propagated from conversation to conversation, from glance to glance. But that unease represented exactly the type of danger that Norland feared most: the risk that the population might begin to think for itself.

enfrentamiento.title: The Final Confrontation between Brothers
enfrentamiento.content_1: The fall of Eldric Reaventhorn did not occur through a spectacular act nor amidst an open revolt. For weeks, his messages spread through factories, universities, and intellectual circles, always transmitted in hushed voices or via discreet pamphlets. That subterranean network grew without visible structure, but its effect became unsettling. Reports reaching the Imperial Council stated the same thing time and again: Eldric's words were infiltrating places where the Empire needed absolute obedience.
enfrentamiento.content_2: House Lovelace, custodian of the Imperial Eye, identified patterns, distribution routes, secret meetings. House Armstrong devised a plan to intercept messengers without alerting the population. And House Ashmere prepared a narrative to be disseminated at the precise moment, moulding public perception even before the outcome was known.
enfrentamiento.content_3: The final operation took place on a silent night in late autumn. Eldric was travelling without escorts, moving between improvised shelters, accompanied only by those who shared his cause. His face was already circulating in internal reports as a target of absolute priority, but he had managed to evade surveillance until that instant. The net, however, had been closing long before he noticed it.
enfrentamiento.content_4: When imperial agents burst into the old warehouse where Eldric was sheltering that night, there was no combat. Only a flash of telegraphic light, a sharp rap against the door, and the voice of a commander announcing that the resistance was over. Eldric's companions were subdued without difficulty. He, however, remained motionless, seated on a crate, aware that his capture could no longer be avoided.
enfrentamiento.content_5: "I knew they would come," he murmured, whilst being handcuffed with reinforced shackles. "This Empire does not tolerate doubt," he expressed with a gaze devoid of a hint of fear.
enfrentamiento.content_6: That same early morning, the official reports sent to the Council declared the operation a complete success: Eldric Reaventhorn, clandestine symbol of opposition, had been handed over to Norland for a private audience. What happened afterwards, only a few were permitted to witness.
enfrentamiento.content_7: The chamber where the final conversation between Norland and Eldric took place had no windows. The only shine came from the Aevar enclosed in glass tubes, whose pale glow cast rigid shadows upon the metal of the walls. The silence was so dense it seemed to absorb the air. Inside there, the Empire did not exist, nor the Council, nor the machinery that already roared beyond the corridors: only two brothers pitted against one another by an irreconcilable vision of the world.
enfrentamiento.content_8: Eldric was chained, but his posture remained upright, almost defiant. The light of the Aevar reflected in his eyes, giving them a firmness that contrasted with the darkness of the room. Norland observed him with the calm of one who has already made an irreversible decision.
enfrentamiento.content_9: "I expected nothing less from you, brother," said Norland, his voice controlled, barely a metallic whisper. "Sentimentality was inevitable; you were always too weak, too human."
enfrentamiento.content_10: Eldric raised his gaze, studying him with a mixture of sadness and lucidity.
enfrentamiento.content_11: "And what are you now, Norland?" he asked without raising his voice. "You traded flesh for metal, soul for calculation. You believe you have built an empire, but what you have erected is a prison. And in it, even the gaolers fear to breathe."
enfrentamiento.content_12: Norland gave a smile that didn't reach his eyes.
enfrentamiento.content_13: "Prisons are necessary when the whole world is a mutiny," he replied, stepping one step closer. "That is the difference between you and me, Eldric. Whilst you dreamt of a perfect liberty, I calculated the price of order."
enfrentamiento.content_14: The chains surrounding Eldric's wrists tinkled when he attempted to straighten up.
enfrentamiento.content_15: "You cannot dominate man forever," he replied firmly.
enfrentamiento.content_16: "I do not intend to dominate him," answered Norland, stopping right in front of him. "I intend to perfect him. The Aevar is not just a mineral; it is evolution. But you... you chose to remain in the past."
enfrentamiento.content_17: Then a prolonged, cutting silence fell, as if the entire room awaited the outcome. Neither looked away. The glow of the Aevar reflected in both a frozen, impersonal hue, as if the mineral itself were attending the final break between blood and ambition.
enfrentamiento.content_18: Finally, Norland turned towards the guard waiting at the entrance. His voice was a simple dictation, devoid of any emotion:
enfrentamiento.content_19: "Ensure he is prepared for dawn. Let history learn what happens to those who confuse freedom with weakness."
enfrentamiento.content_20: The words remained suspended in the air long after Norland left the room. Eldric did not attempt to call out, nor shout, nor beg. He only let the light of the Aevar illuminate his face as he assumed the fate that awaited at the end of that windowless night. The fracture between the brothers was consummated. And with it, the Empire had just sealed the final piece of its new identity.

sacrificio.title: A Sacrifice to Build an Empire
sacrificio.content_1: The Square of Rebirth, still impregnated with the odour of coal and metal that characterised the new industrial era, became the stage destined to mark the definitive transition towards the Empire of Aevora. Thousands of citizens and labourers, summoned by decree, congregated beneath smoking chimneys and loudspeakers that rumbled with precise orders. That crowd was witness, voluntary or not, to an act that was not presented as punishment, but as a foundation.
sacrificio.content_2: Eldric Reaventhorn was led to the centre of the square with his hands tied. He wore a dark coat without insignia, his figure diminished by the vastness of the metallic surroundings. Around him, the voices of the crowd formed a restless murmur that the loudspeakers amplified into fragmented echoes. The bells of Big Ben struck twelve when Norland appeared on a dais of black steel, dressed in the imperial uniform. His presence was sharply silhouetted against the grey background of the sky and smoke, as if the scene had been designed so that no element would distract from his figure.
sacrificio.content_3: Silence fell when he raised his hand. The herald proclaimed the verdict with a ritual coldness:
sacrificio.content_4: "Eldric Reaventhorn, found guilty of sedition, treason, and conspiracy against the imperial order, shall receive death by decree of His Majesty the Emperor of Aevora."
sacrificio.content_5: Norland descended the steps and stopped in front of his brother. For an instant, both observed each other in a silent exchange that contained years of fractures, decisions, and opposing visions of the world.
sacrificio.content_6: "I offered you a place in the new era," said Norland, low enough that only Eldric could hear him, "and you chose the past. May your sacrifice, at least, serve as a foundation."
sacrificio.content_7: Eldric raised his gaze towards the grey sky.
sacrificio.content_8: "Remember, brother, even the strongest iron can rust."
sacrificio.content_9: Norland nodded slightly. And gave the order.
sacrificio.content_10: The shot rang out across the square. The body fell onto the metallic ground, leaving behind a trail of vapour and blood. There was no ceremony to remove it, only an efficient movement of trained guards. From that moment, Eldric's name would be erased from official records and his memory reduced to a warning.
sacrificio.content_11: Norland returned to the dais. The silence of the public, charged with tension, awaited an explanation, a direction, something that would define what they had just witnessed. His voice, projected by the loudspeakers, rumbled amongst the streets of steel:
sacrificio.content_12: "Aevora was born of sacrifice, and today that sacrifice is renewed. Treason does not come from the external enemy, but from the weak heart that doubts. My brother chose chaos, and chaos has been eradicated."
sacrificio.content_13: "Let no one confuse clemency with justice, nor freedom with disorder. We are the fire that purifies, the vapour that propels, the iron that does not break. From today, every citizen shall know that duty is sacred and obedience, a virtue."
sacrificio.content_14: "For Aevora, for order, for the eternity of the Empire!"
sacrificio.content_15: The crowd responded with a unanimous shout:
sacrificio.content_17: The ovation spread like a mechanical roar, reverberating between the iron walls whilst Eldric's body disappeared. With that act, the Empire sealed its identity, without hesitation, without ambiguities, without room for doubt.
sacrificio.content_18: The following months consolidated what had begun in that square. Factories resumed production under the new Production Credit System; banks returned to activity, now under state control; and labourers, converted into cogs in the imperial machinery, received wages and rations in exchange for silence. Meanwhile, in the basements of Whitehall, House Pelwright perfected the first weapons based on refined Aevar, and the Armstrongs worked on the initial models of the Guardians.
sacrificio.content_19: The streets filled with posters bearing the Empire's insignia: a fractured crown atop a gear surrounded by vapour. The words crisis, protest, or dissent disappeared from official terminology, replaced by terms such as efficiency, order, and duty.
sacrificio.content_20: The Empire of Aevora had not only been born of blood, it had been born of vapour, of steel, and of the unwavering will of a leader who demanded that history itself adjust to his design. And once internal control was assured, the next step was inevitable: to take that design beyond the borders.
sacrificio.content_21: That shot, that sacrifice, had not only closed a chapter. It had inaugurated an era.

nobleza.title: The New Nobility
nobleza.content_1: At the apex of this order, floating literally above the smoke and sweat of the world below, stands the New Nobility. Their mansions, palaces of metal and glass, rest upon the so-called High Columns, elevated platforms rising from the heart of the industrial cities like islands of power in a sea of steam and effort. From those heights, the nobles do not gaze upon a world that belongs to them by divine right, but a dominion they have forged with technology, conspiracy, and blood.
nobleza.content_2: Each noble House governs a district or territory with absolute authority, exercising control over the politics, economy, and military force of their fiefdom. They maintain private armies, laboratories where the limits of science are toyed with, and academies where the minds of their heirs are moulded. The children of the nobility are instructed from the cradle in advanced engineering, political economy, and the subtle arts of social control.
nobleza.content_3: Every year, at the solemn Imperial Summit, the patriarchs and matriarchs of the most relevant Houses gather in the great chamber of the Imperial Council. There, under the cold light of Aevar tubes, they renew their oath of loyalty to the Emperor, inhaling the sacred vapour of the mineral that grants them power, longevity, and a dependence as deep as their loyalty. Norland calls them the mind of the Empire, and indeed, they are the architects of its day-to-day existence. But even amongst the architects there exists a hierarchy, the most powerful being the 12 Houses that, alongside Norland, carried out the coup d'état.
nobleza.content_4: The stability of this higher system does not depend on goodwill, but on a complex network of treaties that interweave the destinies of the Houses, creating a balance of power as delicate as the interior of a clock.
nobleza.content_5: Production Treaties regulate the vital flow of resources, refined Aevar, blueprints of advanced machinery, and metallurgy experts. The Major Houses control the energetic core of the Empire, whilst the Minor Houses contribute crucial specialisations: cooling systems to contain the fury of the mineral, logistical networks that traverse continents, and applied research that transforms theories into weapons.
nobleza.content_6: Security Treaties are pacts of blood and steel. They establish that, in the face of any internal threat, a labour uprising, sabotage, or an industrial failure that could be interpreted as treason, the Houses shall come to mutual aid. Private troops cross district borders, always under the watchful eye of the Council, to quell disturbances that could be the spark of a greater fire.
nobleza.content_7: Educational Treaties exchange that which is most valuable: knowledge and the minds of the future. Young heirs are sent as emissaries of learning to the academies of allied (or rival) Houses, forging alliances, absorbing techniques and, above all, internalising that their ultimate loyalty belongs to the Empire, not merely to their surname.
nobleza.content_8: Innovation and Patent Treaties are the most tense and crucial. They regulate the ownership of ideas in a State that lives on constant innovation. Although fierce competition drives progress, imperial law compels the sharing of essential discoveries, those that ensure technological uniformity and, therefore, the indisputable superiority of Aevora. They are the dyke that contains the overflowing ambition of each House, channelling it towards the common benefit of the regime.
nobleza.content_9: But the treaties are merely the framework. The true life of the New Nobility takes place in a state of constant competition, a rivalry orchestrated and fostered by Norland himself. He believes that pressure amongst equals generates excellence, and the structure of the Empire feeds it ceaselessly.
nobleza.content_10: There exists a Productive Rivalry measurable in tonnes of steel, in reactor efficiency, and in armament advancements. The Emperor personally evaluates these metrics, and privileges, exclusive contracts, influence in the Council, and access to Aevar reserves flow towards the most efficient.
nobleza.content_11: Historical tensions and grudges predating the foundation of the Empire continue to pulse beneath the surface. Disputes over talented heirs, covert sabotage in supply chains, and veiled accusations during the Summits... these are the salt that prevents complacency.
nobleza.content_12: Military Competition is waged in joint exercises, spectacles of force where the private armies of the Houses deploy their Guardians and elite troops. Officially, they are tests of coordination; unofficially, they are exhibitions of power to measure strength and remind the other Houses of the weight of each one's war machinery.
nobleza.content_13: All this culminates in the Struggle for Influence in the Imperial Council, a silent battle fought in carpeted corridors and during crucial votes. Each House seeks to control the strategic committees, those that decide upon the development of Aevar, the deployment of Guardians, and the threads of the surveillance network, for from there, one can direct the future of the Empire.
nobleza.content_14: And watching over this clash of titans, always ready to intervene, is the Emperor. When the rivalry threatens to fracture the order he himself has designed, Norland acts with surgical coldness. His sanctions may be economic, territorial, or, in extreme cases, the partial dissolution of a minor House, absorbing its assets and erasing its name, a brutal reminder that, above the Twelve Houses, there is only one will: his own.

militares.title: The Military and Technicians
militares.content_1: Immediately beneath the distant hum of the High Columns beats the stratum that sustains the grandeur of Aevora: the Imperial Military and Technicians. This class represents the forced convergence of brute force and applied knowledge, a fusion of intellect and discipline that keeps the giant of steam and steel alive.
militares.content_2: Their existence elapses within the Iron Rings, fortified districts that seem designed not to be inhabited, but to be operated. Here there is no space for winding streets nor open squares; every alley is a conduit, every building a module, every square an intersection of logistical routes. The city itself is a machine, and its inhabitants, the moving parts within it. The air smells of hot oil, clean steam, and the tense stillness of absolute efficiency.
militares.content_3: Access to this stratum is not an accident of birth, but a cold conquest. It stems from proven technical merit, from the capacity to solve equations under pressure or to dismantle an Aevar reactor with steady hands. However, once inside, loyalty becomes a chain heavier than any armour. Technicians undergo annual scrutiny that goes beyond the professional: psychological tests seeking cracks in their faith, behavioural evaluations measuring every word, every gesture of doubt. The military, for their part, participate in periodic rituals of inhaling refined Aevar vapour. These ceremonies, presented as an honour, reinforce their physical endurance and softly cloud any glimmer of independent thought, exchanging lucidity for an unwavering docility.
militares.content_4: Within this meritocratic and oppressive hierarchy, the fittest ascend to the rank of Custodians. They are the captains of the daily machinery: they oversee factories that roar day and night, direct laboratories where the secrets of Aevar are extracted, and command garrisons that watch over the restless slumber of the Empire. Beneath them, the First Class Operatives form the specialised working mass: men and women who execute complex protocols with the precision of a clock, yet without the right to question the mechanism of which they are a part.
militares.content_5: The Empire defines them as its functional backbone, and it is not mistaken. But it is a spine with exposed nerves and sensitive endings. Every technician, every soldier, not only fulfils their function but acts as a living sensor within the state organism. They have the obligation, branded into the regulations and into their fear, to report any anomaly: a subversive comment from a subordinate, an efficiency that decays without apparent reason, a vacant stare that might suggest a longing for a past world.

obreros.title: The Steam Labourers
obreros.content_1: At the widest and most fundamental base of the social pyramid, where the smoke is thickest and work never ceases, lies the immense multitude of the Steam Labourers. Millions of anonymous souls whose function is not to think, design, or command, but simply to maintain. They sustain upon their backs the weight of the entire productive infrastructure of the Empire.
obreros.content_2: Their cities are not urban centres, but appendages of the great factory complexes. They rise around the factories like mushrooms around a rotting trunk, illuminated permanently by the flickering orange glow of the colossal chimneys. Here, the concept of day and night loses all meaning, devoured by the relentless rhythm of shifts that follow one another without pause. Life is measured in intervals of production, not in hours of sunlight.
obreros.content_3: The economic bond that ties them to the State is absolute and suffocating. The traditional wage has been eradicated and replaced by the Production Credit System. It is not a currency, but a measure of the value of their labour: hours rendered, quotas met, discipline demonstrated. These credits can only be exchanged in state markets for food rations, grey uniforms, basic medicines, and the scarce goods the Council deems appropriate. The system makes saving, private trade, or any glimmer of economic independence impossible. The labouring family lives in total dependency, observed by surveillance automatons and human agents who measure not only their productivity but their conduct inside and outside the workshop.
obreros.content_4: The education of their children is a process of reduction, not growth. They receive only the Instruction of Duty, a programme that teaches functional reading, industrial safety protocols, blind obedience, and elementary mechanics. At thirteen years of age, every child receives their definitive labour designation, a stamp on their identity document that fixes their place in the productive system until death. The majority accept this destiny with a silent resignation, exhausted by toil and surveillance.
obreros.content_5: But in the depths of these districts, where the light of Aevar does not reach and the noise of the machinery drowns out whispers, something stirs. Small clandestine groups emerge, furtive meetings where dreams of a different way of life are shared, where it is remembered, despite the danger, that there was a time before steam and steel. These outbreaks of desire are rare, fragile, and always ephemeral. The Eye Network detects them, and the agents of the Houses extinguish them with speed and exemplary severity, before a spark can threaten the perfectly oiled order of the Empire.

marginados.title: The Outcasts
marginados.content_1: Beyond the last ring of factories, at the limits of the useful world, exists a stratum that not even the social pyramid deigns to illustrate clearly. They are The Outcasts, the human subsoil upon which imperial progress is literally cemented. Here there are no cities, nor neighbourhoods, nor streets; only the entrance to a hell of rock and vapour, and the depths from which springs the soul of the Empire: pure Aevar.
marginados.content_2: In this abyss pile up the refuse of Aevorian society: political prisoners whose only crime was doubt, deserters whose loyalty faltered, dissidents captured with pamphlets in hand, and any soul deemed too weak, too problematic, or simply too expendable for the functioning of the machine. Their sentence is not death, but something the Empire considers worse: absolute utility until the very last breath.
marginados.content_3: Their function is unique and deadly: to extract Aevar in its most volatile and unstable state from the high-toxicity mines. These are not mines; they are maws. Galleries excavated under pressure in the rock, where the air is a thick soup of mineral dust and residual vapour. Surveillance here is not ideological, it is purely biological: guards with masks and authorisation for lethal fire watch every entrance, every lift, every tunnel.
marginados.content_4: Accidents, explosions due to gas accumulation, collapses, acute exposure, are so common that they are not even recorded. A fallen body is quickly dragged away, incinerated in adjacent furnaces, and its ashes, rich in residual mineral, are filtered and reused in industrial processes. It is the imperial doctrine taken to its logical conclusion: nothing is wasted, not even life.
marginados.content_5: In time, the figure of the Outcast ceases to be human and becomes a sombre legend, a tale whispered in the working-class districts to frighten disobedient children. It is rumoured that those who survive long enough in the depths suffer a transformation. Continuous exposure to raw Aevar provokes The Mark: their skin becomes covered in a reddish, scaly tint, and their eyes, adapted to perpetual darkness, reflect a pale and phantasmagorical gleam in the gloom of the caverns.
marginados.content_6: It is said that some no longer speak; they have ceased to be citizens, or even prisoners, to become part of the mine's ecosystem, a living and agonising reminder of the real price of the vapour that drives the Guardians and lights the High Columns. They are the final human fuel, the sordid and unspeakable base upon which rises all the iron splendour of the Empire of Aevora.

vigilancia.title: Control and Surveillance
vigilancia.intro_p1: In the Empire of Aevora, control is not a function of the State; it is its very essence. It is not simply about observing; it is about foreseeing, moulding, and preventing any heartbeat that deviates from the perfect rhythm of the imperial machine. This surveillance is not uniform, but adapts with surgical precision to each stratum of the social pyramid, its intensity being inversely proportional to privilege.
vigilancia.intro_p2: In the High Columns, amongst the New Nobility, control is subtle, elegantly oppressive. It is exercised through orchestrated competition and mutual surveillance. Treaties and Council meetings are stages where every word is weighed, every alliance mapped, and every deviation from Norland's doctrine noted in mental registers of iron.
vigilancia.intro_p3: House Lovelace maintains its Shadows here, agents as well-dressed as their targets, who blend in amongst servants, advisors, or even family members. Betrayal amongst peers is the favourite sport, and the fear of falling from grace, losing privileges, access to refined Aevar, or becoming a target of the Shadows oneself, keeps the elite in a state of calculated loyalty and productive paranoia.
vigilancia.intro_p4: In the Iron Rings, control over the Military and Technicians is an exact science. Work environments are plagued with pressure sensors, performance meters, and vigilant automatons whose crystal eyes record not only productivity but body language, downtime, and elevated heart rates. Annual psychological evaluations are living autopsies, searching for the slightest cracks in the ideological façade.
vigilancia.intro_p5: But the most effective mechanism is horizontal surveillance, the strict obligation of every technician or soldier to report any irregular behaviour in colleagues, subordinates, or even superiors. Omitting a report is as grave as committing the subversive act, transforming every work team into a cage of suspicion where trust is a mortal risk.
vigilancia.intro_p6: In the Cities of the Steam Labourers, control is crude, physical, and constant. Steam cameras with quartz lenses watch every corner, every communal dining hall, every corridor of the housing blocks. Patrol automatons, with their mechanical gait and metallic voices, roam the streets dictating schedules and reminding of quotas. Human supervisors, often promoted from amongst the most submissive labourers, keep detailed records of attendance, efficiency, and moral attitude.
vigilancia.intro_p7: In the Mines of the Outcasts, surveillance is stripped of any pretence. It is purely carceral and terminal. Guards with steam weapons and authorisation for lethal fire watch every entrance, every lift, every gallery. There are no sensors here, only the immediate threat. The life of an Outcast is so disposable that surveillance serves only to prevent mass escapes and ensure that the flow of mineral does not cease. They are observed with the same cold attention paid to a boiler about to explode.
vigilancia.intro_p8: Above all these layers, enveloping the entire Empire like a metal nervous system, operates the Imperial Eye Network. Managed by House Lovelace, it is the brain of surveillance, a vast telegraphic and registry network where agent reports, sensor data, transcripts of intercepted communications, and pattern analyses converge. Here, a whispered conversation in a bar in Glasgow crosses paths with a drop in productivity in a foundry in Birmingham and the unusual movement of a technician in Edinburgh. The Eye seeks correlations, hidden patterns, the ghost of conspiracy before it takes form.

movilidad.title: Social Mobility
movilidad.content_1: In the Empire of Aevora, social mobility is not a lift, but a cell with the floor and ceiling welded shut. Every individual is born, lives, and dies in the stratum the State assigns to them, in a perfect confinement that guarantees productive stability. The system is designed to eliminate expectations, to extinguish the mere dream of a different destiny.
movilidad.content_2: For the Steam Labourer, becoming a Technician is as likely as iron learning to fly. Only in exceptional cases, monitored from infancy by the Imperial Council, can a child with prodigious skills, a mathematical genius in a foundry neighbourhood, hands miraculously steady on an assembly line, be torn from their destiny. This ascent is less a prize than a confiscation: the child is separated from their family, re-educated in a state academy, and watched twice as closely as their new peers, converted into a living example of imperial meritocracy that serves to appease, not to inspire.
movilidad.content_3: Technicians and Military personnel may ascend within their own stratum, from Operative to Custodian, from private to officer. But this ladder ends at an unbreakable glass ceiling. Crossing the border towards the nobility requires an act of valour or utility so extraordinary that it borders on the mythical, saving the life of a Noble in an attack, or discovering a revolutionary application of Aevar in the midst of combat. These cases, recounted and glorified by the propaganda of House Ashmere, are the exception that proves the iron rule. Most ambitious Technicians soon learn that their place is to serve the machine, not to direct it.
movilidad.content_4: The Outcasts have no mobility whatsoever. Their condition is a black hole from which there is no escape. They are the definitive proof that in Aevora there exists only one acceptable direction: downwards, towards extractive utility until annihilation. Any attempt at escape or rebellion is met with immediate death, turning their existence into an objective lesson on the consequences of social failure.
movilidad.content_5: This absolute blockage generates a tense calm, but not total conformism. Here is where social mobilisations arise, although that term is too generous for what occurs in the bowels of the Empire. They are not revolutions, nor even organised protests. They are spasms of desperation, feverish outbreaks that surge in the darkness.
movilidad.content_6: Amongst the Labourers, mobilisation takes the form of a slow and silent sabotage: a lost tool, a poorly made adjustment that delays an assembly line, a rumour coursing through communal dining halls about a lung disease caused by Aevar vapour. Sometimes, on the rare occasions when surveillance is distracted, clandestine pamphlets appear with messages unreadable to automatons, or a simultaneous five-minute stoppage is organised in a foundry, an act of defiance as brief as it is symbolic. These micro-mobilisations are like the blows of a prisoner against the bars of his cell: they do not break them, but they remind everyone, including the gaolers, that the confinement exists.
movilidad.content_7: The Empire's response is instant, systematic, and disproportionate. The Imperial Eye Network, managed by House Lovelace, is specifically designed to detect anomalous patterns before they crystallise into action. An increase in private conversations in a sector, a small drop in productivity, a gathering of three people in an unauthorised location... are sufficient to unleash a Local Purge. Agents enter by night, taking away the alleged instigators and anyone around them. There is no trial. The missing become Outcasts, sent to the mines, or public lessons executed at dawn in front of the factory.

vida.title: Daily Life
vida.intro_p1: In the Empire of Aevora, daily life is not lived, it is executed. Every day is a meticulous repetition of rituals designed to reinforce order, extinguish individuality, and guarantee that the heart of the social machine beats in unison. From the moment the vapour of the sirens announces the first shift until the last operatives shut down in their cubicles, a citizen's existence is a script written in steel by the Imperial Council. Here, routine is synonymous with control, and every aspect of life, learning, leisure, family ties, is just another cog in the machine.

educacion.title: Education by Social Classes
educacion.content_1: Education in Aevora does not illuminate; it programmes. It is a process of surgical implantation where each stratum receives the software necessary for its function, eliminating any surplus line of code such as doubt or creativity.
educacion.content_2: In the High Columns, the academies of the nobility are hothouses of calculated ambition. Here, the children of each House do not learn; they train. Their classrooms are war rooms with blackboards; they study siege engineering alongside classical poetry, not for pleasure, but to understand the psyche of the cultures they must dominate. Political economy is taught as the art of extracting efficiency from a territory, and military theory as an extension of pure logic.
educacion.content_3: There are no exams with marks; there are aptitude evaluations carried out by imperial ministers. An heir who shows too much compassion receives corrective tuition. One who shows a ruthless technical genius is marked for high command. Their education is a long process of sculpting not scholars, but administrators of empires.
educacion.content_4: In the Iron Rings, the industrial-military academies are extensions of the factory. Knowledge is utilitarian and urgent. Students, destined to be Technicians or Command Cadres, memorise diagrams of Aevar reactors before learning to write with elegance. Their curriculum is a constant diet of applied mathematics, vapour chemistry, Guardian maintenance protocols, and basic squad tactics.
educacion.content_5: History lessons glorify Norland's coup and imperial efficiency. The day includes hours of physical training under light vapour, conditioning both body and mind for obedience. Here, a student does not graduate; he is certified as an operative and assigned to his post, beginning a cycle of perpetual evaluations that will not end until his death or his discarding.
educacion.content_6: In the working-class districts, education is a process of reduction. The Instruction of Duty is a compendium of the bare minimum: recognising danger signs in a factory, following simple verbal orders, performing basic arithmetic operations to count parts. Obedience is taught through repetition, loyalty to the Empire through hymns sung in unison, and the value of work as the ultimate end of existence.
educacion.content_7: At thirteen years of age, without ceremony, every child receives their Labour Designation: a stamp on their document, an assignment to a specific machine. There is no vocational guidance, because there is no vocation. There is only function. The classroom is abandoned forever, and the factory becomes their entire universe.
educacion.content_8: For the Outcasts, education is an oxymoron. There are no schools, only practical demonstrations on the edge of death. A foreman points to a vein of raw Aevar and grunts an order. Learning to extract it without killing oneself or others is the only lesson. Ignorance is their natural state and their condemnation; knowledge, a privilege reserved for the useful.

cultura.title: Culture and Entertainment
cultura.content_1: In Aevora, culture is not expression, it is social engineering. Every book, every symphony, every spectacle is a tool to polish the human cog, eliminating the rough edges of independent thought.
cultura.content_2: For the Nobility, culture is a battlefield of prestige. They attend concerts where compositions glorify the power of steam and the harmony of machinery. They visit exhibitions of the latest Guardian prototypes, where aesthetics merge with lethality. Their salons are arenas for technical debates disguised as social gatherings, where a sharp wit can gain influence for their House. Even their leisure is productive: they hunt with precision steam rifles, not for sport, but to exercise marksmanship and cold blood. Here, having fun is another form of competing and reaffirming their place at the apex.
cultura.content_3: For Technicians and Military, entertainment is a simulacrum of service. In the canteens of the Iron Rings, screens project documentaries about engineering feats or victorious military manoeuvres. They have access to combat gyms and tactical simulation rooms, where what for others is a game, for them is continuous training. They may read updated technical manuals or the scarce novels approved by the Cultural Council, stories of heroism and sacrifice that always end with loyalty to the Empire rewarded. Any personal artistic creation must be previously approved and is usually channelled towards functional designs: an emblem for their unit, an ergonomic improvement for a tool. Creativity for pleasure is considered a dangerous distraction.
cultura.content_4: For the Steam Labourers, culture is a sedative administered by the State. Their entertainments are collective, passive, and didactic. In public squares, giant screens show spectacles of unity: choreographies of thousands of workers, inaugurations of new factories, or broadcast speeches of the Emperor. State theatres, of cold and utilitarian architecture, perform simple plays where the hero is always the obedient labourer who overcomes a crisis thanks to his faith in the system, and the villain, the idler or the doubter. Festivities commemorate production milestones; they are days of rest granted, not earned, always with the shadow that leisure is a concession, not a right.
cultura.content_5: For the Outcasts, culture does not exist. There is no music, nor stories, nor images. Their sensory world is reduced to the rumble of controlled explosions, the hiss of vapour in cooling pipes, and the taste of Aevar dust in the mouth. Their entertainment, if it can be called that, is the survival of one more shift. The only art they know is that of avoiding death for one more day, and their galleries are the rock walls stained red by the mineral that consumes them.

familia.title: Family and Social Relations
familia.content_1: The family in the Empire is a unit of production and control, stripped of sentimentality in favour of state efficiency. Blood ties are evaluated by their utility to the regime.
familia.content_2: In the Nobility, the family is a dynastic corporation. Marriages are strategic mergers negotiated between Houses, treaties of blood to ensure alliances, share technology, or absorb minor rivals. Love is an irrelevant variable. Children are, above all, heirs to a legacy of power. Their upbringing is delegated to governesses, specialised tutors, and military instructors from earliest infancy. Parents act as executive directors, supervising the development of their main product to guarantee it meets the Empire's standards. Affections are expressed as approval for achievements, and disappointments as reports of low performance.
familia.content_3: Amongst Technicians and Military, family is permitted, but strictly subordinate to duty. Cohabitation permits are granted according to production cycles and campaigns. An ideal couple is one formed by two specialists whose skills complement one another and whose performance does not decay after forming a household. Children are cared for in state nurseries from the first months, where they receive the appropriate stimulation for their future stratum. Family time is scarce, regulated, and often monitored to detect if conjugal loyalty interferes with loyalty to the Empire. A cold and professional camaraderie is fostered over emotional intimacy.
familia.content_4: In Labourer families, a vestige of the traditional structure persists, but under a distorted lens. Couples are usually formed within the same district or factory complex, out of pure proximity. Family life takes place in the cramped apartments of the state blocks, always with the sensation that the walls have ears. Exhaustive twelve-hour shifts steal time and energy, reducing interaction to silent meals and sleep. Children, educated by the State, often see their parents more as examples of resigned fatigue than as figures of affective authority. The State, through supervisors and credit systems, intrudes in every decision, from family planning to the allocation of larger housing. The labourer family is not a refuge, but one more cell in the structure of control.
familia.content_5: For the Outcasts, the concept of family has been atomised by horror. In the overcrowded barracks of the mining camps, ties are formed and broken with the brutal speed of a collapse. Couples are ephemeral; children, if they survive birth in those conditions, are soon separated for tasks suited to their size. There are no surnames to bequeath, nor homes to build, nor a future to plan. The only social relationship that endures is that of fellow sufferers, a bond based on the mutual instinct for survival, often betrayed at the slightest promise of an extra ration or a less deadly shift.

economia.title: Imperial Economy
economia.intro_p1: The economy of the Empire of Aevora is structured as a completely centralised system, designed to maximise productive efficiency and ensure the State's absolute control over every resource generated. It operates neither under market principles nor under traditional models of commercial exchange; instead, it relies on total planning, the perpetual recording of productivity, and the direct conversion of human labour into energy, infrastructure, and military expansion.
economia.intro_p2: The Empire considers that the principal economic function is not to create individual wealth, but to feed the state machinery, sustain the war industry, and guarantee the continuity of the social order. All economic activities, from mining to scientific research, respond directly to the needs set by the Imperial Council and supervised by the Emperor.

creditos.title: Production Credit System
creditos.content_1: The heartbeat of this economy is not marked by gold, but by the Production Credit. It is not a currency, but a measure of obedience. Its value does not fluctuate on trade exchanges, but is calculated with bureaucratic precision based on hours worked, quotas exceeded, and, above all, discipline demonstrated. A labourer does not earn credits; he generates them through his function in the machine.
creditos.content_2: These credits are a mirage of economic freedom. They can only be exchanged in state markets, austere warehouses where food rations calculated to the gram, identical uniforms, basic medicines, and the scarce non-essential goods the Council judges convenient for productive morale are dispensed. The system is designed to make significant saving or private trade impossible. Why accumulate credits if there is nothing valuable to buy outside the system? Economic dependence is total and deliberate.
creditos.content_3: Amongst the Steam Labourers, the credit becomes a whip. A reduction in the allocation is the first punishment for a fault: arriving late, failing to reach the quota, being caught in a subversive conversation. It is a sanction felt in the stomachs of one's children, a physical reminder that survival is tied to submission.
creditos.content_4: In the upper strata, the credit is combined with more subtle but equally controlling privileges: access to personal doses of refined Aevar that sharpen the senses and delay fatigue, priority for housing in less polluted zones, and permits to travel between districts. They are crumbs from the banquet of power, sufficient to create a loyal and dependent elite, but never abundant enough to buy true autonomy.

comercio.title: Internal and External Trade
comercio.interior_p1: Within the Empire's borders, trade is not an exchange, but a logistical redistribution. The concept of a free market does not exist. Instead, there is a constant and regulated flow of resources from extraction and production points towards consumption centres and the High Columns.
comercio.interior_p2: This flow is governed by three unbreakable principles:
comercio.interior_p3: Distribution by Decree: Quotas of food, raw materials, spare parts, and manufactured goods are decided by the Imperial Economy Council. A mining district receives so many rations and such a type of machinery, not according to what it needs, but according to what the Central Plan determines as optimal for general production.
comercio.interior_p4: Militarised Transport: Every train convoy, every river freighter, is a military operation. They are escorted by light Guardians or troops of the Steam Legion. It is not only for defence against an improbable external insurgency; it is to prevent diversions, internal sabotage, or the emergence of a black market that could flourish on the route between the foundry and the armoury.
comercio.interior_p5: Total Traceability: Every barrel of Aevar, every crate of ammunition, bears a unique Aevar pressure seal. This seal, a complex energetic signature, allows agents of the Eye Network to track its location in real time through the telegraphic network. A resource that disappears from its pre-authorised route triggers a treason investigation.
comercio.interior_p6: This system ensures that no district, no House, however powerful, can accumulate enough resources to become autonomous. Economic centralisation is the cement that holds the political empire together.
comercio.exterior_p1: Towards the outside world, the Empire turns its gaze not as a merchant, but as a strategist using the economy as a weapon of influence. External trade is exceptional, minimalist, and deeply strategic.
comercio.exterior_p2: The Empire exports only what it decides. Obsolete technology, previous versions of steam rifles, heavy machinery designs that have already been surpassed internally. Controlled surpluses, such as excess medium-quality steel, non-critical chemical compounds. The promise of energy, limited and exceedingly expensive access to small quantities of refined Aevar, acts as a tool of blackmail over dependent nations.
comercio.exterior_p3: In exchange, it imports only that which it does not suit it to produce. Exotic raw materials, such as rubber, certain rare minerals, luxury foods that do not grow in its cold and polluted climate. And Information; through opaque transactions, it obtains rumours, maps, and scientific data stolen from other countries.
comercio.exterior_p4: This trade is not in the hands of businessmen, but of the Major Houses, whose agents act as ambassador-merchants. A negotiation by House Cunard for port routes is, in reality, a naval reconnaissance. A loan from House Rothschild to a border nation is the placing of an economic noose around its neck.
comercio.exterior_p5: The objective is never commercial profit in itself, but to expand the sphere of influence, weaken rivals, and prepare the ground for the day when diplomacy gives way, once again, to conquest. In the economy of Aevora, even the most peaceful exchange is a phase of perpetual war.

fundacion.title: Foundation
